Group B targeting is likely to secure higher AOV.
Decision Rule: Reject the null if AOV is above or 500$: Target group B instead of group A as more likely to be the targeting that maximizes the AOV.

In simple terms, the hypothesis is that we should target group B instead of A, but this decision, could lead to an error called type 1 error and we can quantify it, there are 2 chances out of 20 (count right to left after red mark) to be wrong, hence 10% chance of rejecting the null when the null is in fact true.

Decision: we should target group A instead of B, but this decision, could lead to an error called type 2 error and we can quantify it, there are 5 chances out of 20 (count left to right before red mark) to be wrong, hence a 25 % chance of rejecting the alternative when Alternative is true
𝑝̂ = proportions sampled | n = sample size
Simple Function in R to calculate confidence interval based on a 95% interval using 1.96 Z score.

In Plain English, a 95% confidence interval quantifies a range of reasonable values for our parameter within the sample. Based on our sample of 20 users who purchased in group A, with 95% confidence, we estimate between 8.5% and 11.5% of all such users who purchase above 500$ AOV.
5. Conservative Approach & Sample Size

We estimate that the true interval of the un-sampled population of group A is around -5% to 25% chances of having users who purchase above a 500$ AOV
Example of a sample size needed to have a 95% confidence interval with a margin of error of 3%.
We would need at least 1112 users per sample size to make the results significant with a 3% margin of error.

Interpreting the 95% confidence interval, we are 95% confident that the AOV of all the population is estimated to be between 327$ and 477$
The 4 main steps to hypothesis testing:
Is the group B with higher AOV better targeting that AOV of group A because of age above 40 years?
p1 = Group A (below or equal to 40 years)
Test for significance difference in AOV in the population proportions of above 40 years with a 10% (𝛼) significance level.
H1: p1-p2 ≠0 (alternative hypotesis or reject the null difference between p1 and p2)
𝛼 = 10 % (significance level at 10% if p value less than 10% we can consider the effect significant)
Lift In AOV: Δ = ∑ [AOV per user group A] — ∑ [AOV per user group B]

Great, now that we have our delta of -275$ per user in Group A, let’s make sure that we met our alpha condition of 10% so we can reject the null hypothesis; And go with the alternative = Target Group B.
Let’s test our significance using a Test Statistic:
The Zscore of -3.1 translating into a p-value of 0,07% hence we are above 99% confident that our results are significant.
Let’s visualize the Zscore and P-value. using a normal distribution with mean 0 and standard deviation 1 (0,1)

The effect is very unlikely to be driven by chance hence can be consider the uplift significant in AOV in group B compared to group A based on the data sampled. Important to remeber that the p value is not the probability of the decision being true, the null statement H0 or the altnerative H1 is either true or false, the p value captures the probability of the data being true under a certain theory.

That would be my summary for the frequentist approach, I have shared the R code and formulas so you can easily replicate it and learn the fundamentals by doing. Now let’s have a look at the other approach to A/B testing, the Bayesian approach.
For simplicity, we will use the same data frame we will have a quick view of the math behind it, despite not the purpose of this article.

Typically most A/B tests are performed using the frequentist approach, however Bayesian is in my view much more practical and interpretable. In simple terms instead of p-values you get direct probabilities on whether A is better than B.
A, B = eventsP(A|B) = probability of A given B is trueP(B|A) = probability of B given A is trueP(A), P(B) = the independent probabilities of A and B
As observed the group A has 30% CVR versus group B an 80% CVR — the conversion being the event of having an AOV above 400$, the mean of the population sample.
We can have fun plugging the results to check the likelihood that group B is better than group A based on our hypothesis of having an AOV above 500$.
Without surprise group, B has a 100% probability of being stronger than group A. In my view this result is much easier to interpret than the p-value in the frequentist approach.
Question: How likely it is that group B secures higher AOV than group A?

We first need a metric of success, we will count the number of times in both groups than AOV is above 400$ and define that as conversion, hence our conversion rate noted CVR is: (Transactions > 400$/Total transactions) per group.
Let’s do the exercise and plot a table.
We could express that with the bayesian rule.
A, B = eventsP(A|B) = how often A happens given that B happensP(B|A) = how often B happens given that A happens,P(A), P(B) = the independent probabilities of A and B
For example, if the probability of a model is 10% then there is a 1:10 chance that group B is more effective than A.
Should reflect the state of our belief prior to the experiment and incorporate as much information as possible from other experiments, industry benchmarks, etc.
But for this example, we assume the closest as a Null hypothesis than group B is not better than group A with a 52% prior belief in the V5 model.
Let’s breakdown the Bayes rule again and calculate in R manually without any library.

Summing up from V6 to V9 we get a 92.2% probability that group B is stronger than A. Despite our prior was at 52% on V5, the model adjusted the posterior based on the Bayes rule, and allow us to reject the null and go with the alternative.

In a nutshell: We have seen the main conceptual differences between Frequentist and Bayesian with a very simple and practical A/B testing eCom example - I hope this was a clear introduction, and please feel free to DM for any question!
